content: The "Facilitating Access to Speedy Transmissions for Networks, E-commerce and Telecommunications (FASTNET) Act" is the short title of the legislation. The purpose of the Act is to facilitate access to speedy transmissions for networks, e-commerce, and telecommunications. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 aimed to promote competition and reduce regulation in telecommunications markets nationwide. It recognized the unique circumstances of local exchange carriers with fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines. The Telecommunications Act of 1996 acknowledged the unique position of local exchange carriers with less than two percent of the nation's subscriber lines, enabling them to accelerate the deployment of advanced services in less densely populated regions. Existing regulations tailored to larger carriers often burden these smaller carriers disproportionately, hindering their progress. Reducing regulatory burdens on two percent carriers will allow them to allocate more resources to deploying advanced services and competitive initiatives in less densely populated regions of the Nation. Reducing regulatory burdens on two percent carriers will enable them to allocate more resources to deploying advanced services and competitive initiatives in less densely populated regions of the Nation, accelerating deployment for the benefit of consumers. The Act aims to accelerate the deployment of advanced services and promote competition in the telecommunications industry for the benefit of consumers nationwide, particularly in less densely populated regions. It seeks to reduce regulatory burdens on local exchange carriers with fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines, allowing them more flexibility to undertake such initiatives. The Act aims to reduce regulatory burdens on local exchange carriers with less than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines, improving their flexibility and allowing them to redirect resources to increase investment in initiatives. SEC. 3. DEFINITION. Section 3 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 153) is amended to define a 'two percent carrier' as an incumbent local exchange carrier with fewer than a certain number of access lines. Section 251(h) defines a 'two percent carrier' as an incumbent local exchange carrier with access lines that are fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines nationwide. SEC. 4. Regulatory relief for two percent carriers under Title II of the Communications Act of 1934, with reduced regulatory requirements for carriers with fewer than two percent of the Nation's subscriber lines. The Commission must consider the impact of regulatory requirements on two percent carriers when adopting rules for incumbent local exchange carriers. If the Commission fails to do so, they cannot enforce the rule against two percent carriers until they evaluate the burden separately. The Commission must evaluate the impact of regulatory requirements on two percent carriers when adopting rules for incumbent local exchange carriers. If they fail to do so, the rule cannot be enforced against two percent carriers until a separate evaluation is conducted. Size-based differentiation among carriers mandated by the rules is not prohibited. The Commission must evaluate regulatory impact on two percent carriers when adopting rules for incumbent local exchange carriers. If rules do not apply to two percent carriers, they are exempt. Differentiation based on carrier size mandated by the rules is allowed. Nothing in this section prohibits size-based differentiation among carriers. Effective date applies to rules adopted after enactment of this section. "SEC. 282. LIMITATION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS." The Commission is limited in requiring a two percent carrier to file cost allocation manuals or ARMIS reports, except for section 224 purposes. The carrier must certify compliance with cost allocation rules annually. The Commission's authority is preserved, except as specified. The Commission can require two percent carriers to file ARMIS reports, except for section 224 purposes. The Commission's authority to access information is preserved under certain sections. SEC. 283. INTEGRATED OPERATION OF TWO PERCENT CARRIERS. The Commission will not require any two percent carrier to have a separate affiliate for providing various services, including local and long-distance services, mobile radio services, internet, and other enhanced services. Additionally, carriers and their affiliates are not mandated to maintain separate personnel, facilities, departments, or operations. SEC. 284 states about participation in tariff pools and price cap regulation. The participation or withdrawal from a common line tariff by a two percent carrier administered by NECA or any successor shall not obligate the carrier for other study areas. The Commission may require a 60-day notice for participation or withdrawal. The carrier's election is binding for one year. A two percent carrier can elect to withdraw from or participate in common line tariff or price cap rate regulation for specific study areas. The carrier's election is binding for one year. The Commission allows carriers to make elections regarding common line tariff or price cap rate regulation for specific study areas. A carrier's election is binding for one year, and it is not required to make the same election for other study areas. SEC. 285. DEPLOYMENT OF NEW TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES BY TWO PERCENT COMPANIES. The Commission allows two percent carriers to introduce new interstate telecommunications services with only one day's notice, without needing approval for the rate structure. The term 'new interstate telecommunications service' refers to services not previously offered by the carrier. The term 'new interstate telecommunications service' refers to a class or subclass of service not previously offered by the carrier, allowing two percent carriers to introduce such services with only one day's notice without needing rate structure approval. "SEC. 286. ENTRY OF COMPETING CARRIER." "Two percent carriers can adjust interstate rates with short notice and offer contract-based tariffs upon certification of competition in their service area." Two percent carriers can adjust interstate rates with short notice and offer contract-based tariffs upon certification of competition in their service area. Streamlined Pricing Regulation allows carriers to compute their interstate rate of return based on the nondiscounted rate for the service. Upon certification of competition in their service area, the Commission will regulate a two percent carrier as non-dominant and exempt them from tariffing interstate service offerings. Upon certification of competition in their service area, the Commission will regulate a two percent carrier as non-dominant and exempt them from tariffing interstate service offerings. The carrier may participate in the common line tariff by including their study areas. "Facilities-based entry" refers to operating within the carrier's service area. The term 'facilities-based entry' in the context of a two percent carrier refers to providing local telephone exchange switching and service to at least one unaffiliated customer. 'Contract-based tariff' is defined as a tariff based on a service contract. The term 'contract-based tariff' refers to a tariff based on a service contract between a two percent carrier and one or more customers, including contract terms, service descriptions, and volume commitments. Amendment to the Communications Act of 1934 sets a deadline for making public interest determinations in mergers involving two percent carriers. The Commission must make required determinations and rule on waiver petitions related to the merger or acquisition. The Commission must make determinations and rule on waiver petitions related to mergers involving two percent carriers within 60 days of receiving an application. If no action is taken within this timeframe, the application is deemed approved. The Commission must approve or deny merger applications involving two percent carriers within 60 days. If no action is taken, the application is deemed approved without conditions. The Commission must approve or deny merger applications involving two percent carriers within 60 days. A carrier can elect under section 284 for local exchange facilities acquired through a merger or acquisition subject to the review deadline. Effective immediately for new applications, existing applications will be subject to these provisions as if newly filed. Applications submitted to the Commission after the enactment of this Act will be subject to new requirements. Pending applications at the time of enactment will also be subject to these new rules as if they were filed on the enactment date. SEC. 6. TIME LIMITS FOR ACTION ON PETITIONS FOR RECONSIDERATION OR WAIVER. Section 405 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to include a provision for expedited action by the Commission on petitions for reconsideration or waiver. The Commission must issue an order granting or denying such petitions within 90 days, or the relief sought will be deemed granted. The Commission must act on petitions for reconsideration or waiver within 90 days. Failure to do so will result in the relief sought being deemed granted. Enforcement of any rule specifically sought for reconsideration will be stayed until the Commission issues an order on the petition. The Commission must act on petitions for reconsideration or waiver within 90 days. Failure to do so will result in the relief sought being deemed granted. Enforcement of any rule specifically sought for reconsideration will be stayed until the Commission issues an order on the petition. Any order issued or grant of a petition for waiver will be final and may be appealed. The provisions apply to petitions submitted on or after the effective date. The provisions of this section apply to petitions for reconsideration or waiver submitted to the Commission on or after the date of enactment. Pending petitions will be subject to these requirements as if filed on the enactment date. SEC. 7. NATIONAL SECURITY AND LAW ENFORCEMENT EXCEPTIONS. National security and law enforcement exceptions exempt certain petitions or applications from time constraints under the Communications Act of 1934 if Executive Branch agencies with national security, law enforcement, or public safety responsibilities submit a written filing to the FCC. Executive Branch agencies, such as the Department of Defense, Department of Justice, and the FBI, can advise the FCC in writing if a petition or application raises national security, law enforcement, or public safety concerns that cannot be resolved within the specified time period.
